item.title: SilkAir will begin flying between Okinawa and Japan in January 2015
item.description:
SilkAir, the regional subsidiary of Singapore Airlines, will launch its inaugural charter flights between Singapore and Okinawa, Japan. Operated in partnership with Okinawa Tourist Service (OTS) and Jumbo Tours Okinawa, these monthly charters will run from September 9, 2014, to January 3, 2015. Utilizing Boeing 737-800 aircraft with both business and economy class seating, these direct flights aim to provide travelers with a convenient option to visit Okinawa. From September to October 2014, flights will depart Singapore Changi Airport Terminal 2 at 10:00 am and arrive at Okinawa Naha Airport at 4:15 pm...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/silkair-will-begin-flying-between-okinawa-and-japan-in-january-2015/

item.title: The CJEU missed an opportunity to address mass hacking and fundamental rights.
item.description:
Hugo Partouche, a Paris Bar Attorney-at-law (avocat), and Chloé Berthélémy, a Senior Policy Advisor at EDRi, collaborated on this piece. Photo credit: hacker-silhoutte, via Wikimedia commons *This article initially appeared in French in Actualité Juridique (AJ) Pénal, Dalloz Revues. You can find it here. The Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) issued its decision on the ‘EncroChat’ case on April 30, 2024. This case arose from large-scale European police operations targeting organized crime...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/the-cjeu-missed-an-opportunity-to-address-mass-hacking-and-fundamental-rights/

item.title: Is there more that the EU and its Member States can do to combat Holocaust denial and hate crime?
item.description:
Steve Peers Coinciding with International Holocaust Remembrance Day, the European Commission has released its initial assessment of how EU member states are putting into action the EU Framework Decision. This legislation addresses combating racism and xenophobia through criminal law. Putting EU Law into Practice EU member states were obligated to incorporate this law, a carryover from the pre-Lisbon Treaty era, by December 2010. The Council was then expected to evaluate the member states’ progress based on the Commission’s report by November 2013...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/is-there-more-that-the-eu-and-its-member-states-can-do-to-combat-holocaust-denial-and-hate-crime/

item.title: The ECJ ruling in Joined Cases C-203/15 and C-698/15 Tele2 and Watson (Grand Chamber) on data retention and national law.
item.description:
Lorna Woods, Professor of Internet Law, University of Essex Introduction A recent court decision examined the legality of national data retention laws from a human rights standpoint. These laws remained in effect even after the Data Retention Directive was struck down in the Digital Rights Ireland case due to its disproportionate impact on Articles 7 and 8 of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights (EUCFR). This judgment clarifies the interpretation of Articles 7 and 8 within EU law, particularly in the context of the Privacy and Electronic Communications Directive, and may impact the UK’s relationship with the EU post-Brexit...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/the-ecj-ruling-in-joined-cases-c-203-15-and-c-698-15-tele2-and-watson-grand-chamber-on-data-retention-and-national-law/

item.title: SilkAir will provide direct charter flights to Okinawa
item.description:
To encourage travel between Singapore and Okinawa, SilkAir, the Okinawa Prefecture government, Japan, and Changi Airport Group are collaborating on seven direct SilkAir charter flights. These flights will operate between June 1st and 25th, 2016, connecting Singapore and Okinawa, Japan’s southernmost prefecture. Travelers can book these full-service flights through Singapore travel agents. SilkAir’s Boeing 737-800 aircraft, featuring Business and Economy class cabins, will service the route. Passengers will enjoy a comprehensive range of full-service offerings, including a baggage allowance of 30kg for Economy and 40kg for Business class, inflight meals, and complimentary inflight entertainment through SilkAir Studio...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/silkair-will-provide-direct-charter-flights-to-okinawa/

item.title: Is it possible for EU law to rescue Paddington Bear? The CJEU is creating a new form of protection.
item.description:
Many people might already know about Colin Yeo’s blog post that imagines Paddington Bear having a tough time with British immigration law. However, could EU law potentially protect Paddington, particularly by offering a new kind of protection for those forced to leave their home countries? Background EU law has detailed rules for two types of international protection: refugee status (based on the UN’s Geneva Convention) and subsidiary protection status for those who don’t qualify as refugees...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/is-it-possible-for-eu-law-to-rescue-paddington-bear-the-cjeu-is-creating-a-new-form-of-protection/

item.title: Tarakhel v Switzerland: Is this the end of the Dublin system?
item.description:
Dublin System Challenged Again: Tarakhel v Switzerland Introduction Despite aiming for high human rights protection standards, the EU’s Dublin system, which assigns responsibility for each asylum-seeker to one Member State, has repeatedly encountered human rights issues. The recent European Court of Human Rights (‘ECtHR’) judgments in Tarakhel v Switzerland and Sharifi v Italy and Greece further highlight the difficulties in aligning this system with ECHR obligations. Notably, the Tarakhel judgment goes beyond previous rulings by demonstrating that the Court of Justice of the European Union’s (CJEU) interpretation of the Dublin rules also conflicts with the ECHR...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/tarakhel-v-switzerland-is-this-the-end-of-the-dublin-system/
